abstracts.cdata!:
The Watershed and Environmental
            Management Project for St. Lucia is rated as having
            satisfactory overall outcome. All the development objectives
            were achieved. Overall Bank performance is rated as highly
            satisfactory. The sustainability of project outputs will
            depend significantly on the availability of funds. Borrower
            performance in preparation of the project is rated as highly
            satisfactory, while in project implementation it is rated as
            satisfactory. The key factors affecting the performance
            were: rapid project processing; strong borrower ownership;
            flexible procurement procedures; effective civil works
            maintenance; stringent environmental guidelines; and
            positive social impact. The key lessons learned are as
            follows. Quick, effective, and coordinated response from the
            Bank and other lending agencies is fundamental to achieving
            satisfactory results in emergency situations. The
            Bank's acceptance of maximum flexibility of procurement
            procedures for civil works and goods was of critical
            importance to ensuring fast implementation. However,
            environmental guidelines need to be infringed upon because
            of necessary speed in design or execution of civil works. An
            adequate balance should be sought between swiftness in
            action, accuracy in design, compliance with environmental
            guidelines, and proper use of local knowledge. The active
            participation of affected communities is important in
            achieving effective and sustainable management of watershed
            areas. The infusion of local knowledge from national staff
            can be important in the design of emergency operations,
            especially given the short time window and complicated
            nature of the interventions. Finally, the experience of this
            project illustrates how strong Borrower ownership and
            commitment contributes to smooth, effective, and timely implementation.
